DataElement.preferredName: Subjective Numeracy Scale How Useful Tables and Graphs Accompanying Newspaper or Other Text Score_6 Point Scale
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A person's stated perception of how helpful he/she finds tables and graphs that are part of a written text, using a six-point likert scale.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Subjective Numeracy Scale How Useful Tables and Graphs Accompanying Newspaper or Other Text
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A self-report measure of perceived ability to perform various mathematical tasks and preference for the use of numerical versus prose information. The 8-item scale contains no mathematics questions and has no correct or incorrect answers. Instead, it consists of 4 questions asking respondents to assess their numerical ability in different contexts and 4 questions asking them to state their preferences for the presentation of numerical and probabilistic information. (Fagerlin, et al., Medical Decision Making, 2007: 27: 672-680)_A survey question about how useful a person finds tables and graphs that accompnay a newspaper story or other text.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A self-report measure of perceived ability to perform various mathematical tasks and preference for the use of numerical versus prose information. The 8-item scale contains no mathematics questions and has no correct or incorrect answers. Instead, it consists of 4 questions asking respondents to assess their numerical ability in different contexts and 4 questions asking them to state their preferences for the presentation of numerical and probabilistic information. (Fagerlin, et al., Medical Decision Making, 2007: 27: 672-680)

Concepts.definition: A self-report measure of perceived ability to perform various mathematical tasks and preference for the use of numerical versus prose information. The 8-item scale contains no mathematics questions and has no correct or incorrect answers. Instead, it consists of 4 questions asking respondents to assess their numerical ability in different contexts and 4 questions asking them to state their preferences for the presentation of numerical and probabilistic information. (Fagerlin, et al., Medical Decision Making, 2007: 27: 672-680)

Property.preferredName: How Useful Tables and Graphs Accompanying Newspaper or Other Text
Property.preferredDefinition: A survey question about how useful a person finds tables and graphs that accompnay a newspaper story or other text.

Concepts.longName: How Useful Tables and Graphs Accompanying Newspaper or Other Text
Concepts.definition: A question about how useful an individual finds or found tables and graphs that accompany a newspaper story or other text.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Numeric code to represent how helpful something is using a six-point Likert scale.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subjective answer of no agreement or ability.

Concepts.definition: A subjective answer of no agreement or ability.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Extremely Helpful Not at all Six Range Likert Score 2

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Extremely Helpful Not at all Six Range Likert Score 2
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A subjective answer of strong agreement regarding the helpfulness of something.:A subjective answer of non-agreement.:A natural number greater than 5 and less than 7 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of five and one.:The difference between the lowest and highest numerical values; the limits or scale of variation.:A subjective score of 2 on a Likert scale.

Concepts.definition: A subjective answer of extreme agreement regarding the helpfulness of something.
A subjective answer of no agreement or ability.
A natural number greater than 5 and less than 7 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of five and one.
The difference between the lowest and highest numerical values; the limits or scale of variation.
A subjective score of 2 on a Likert scale.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Modified long name/definition to meet quality criteria and released as part of caDSR cleanup. mc 7/2/12

ReferenceDocuments.name: When reading the newspaper, h
ReferenceDocuments.description: When reading the newspaper, how helpful do you find tables and graphs that are parts of a story?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Scoring Instructions
ReferenceDocuments.description: All questions scored as marked (1-6) except Question 7 which is reverse coded (6-1). SNS: Average rating across all 8 questions (w/ Q7 reverse coded) SNS ability subscale: Average rating on Questions 1-4 SNS preference subscale: Average rating on Questions 5-8 (w/ Q7 reverse coded)

ReferenceDocuments.name: Author Names
ReferenceDocuments.description: Fagerlin A, Zikmund-Fisher BJ, Ubel PA, Jankovic A, Derry HA, Smith DM

ReferenceDocuments.name: Measure Citation
ReferenceDocuments.description: Measuring numeracy without a math test: Development of the Subjective Numeracy Scale (SNS). Medical Decision Making, 2007: 27: 672-680.

DataElement.changeDescription: Modified long name/definition and added question text to meet quality criteria and released as part of caDSR cleanup. mc 7/2/12
